webTitle: County cricket: Essex crowned champions after draw at Somerset – as it happened

fields.headline: County cricket: Essex crowned champions after draw at Somerset – as it happened
fields.standfirst: Essex kept their nerve to hold out for a draw against Somerset after a first-innings collapse to win a second County Championship in three seasons
fields.trailText: Over-by-over report: Essex kept their nerve to hold out for a draw against Somerset after a first-innings collapse to win a second County Championship in three seasons
fields.byline: Tanya Aldred at Taunton (earlier) and Tom Davies (later)
fields.body:
9.49pm BST

Related: Alastair Cook steadies Essex nerves in County Championship triumph

Related: Simon Harmer proves the man for all season in Essex’s title triumph | Tanya Aldred

5.49pm BST

Summing up

Well, it’s not easy to sum up this season in a few words. It’s been a blast, from T20 to World Cups to Ashes to a championship that went to the wire, between its two best teams who even amid ridiculous autumn weather managed to rustle us up a finish today with some twists and turns, particularly turns on a textbook Ciderabad pitch. Congrats Essex, commiserations Somerset, and thanks to everyone including you, our readers, for a wonderful long summer of cricket. See you again soon. Bye.

5.46pm BST

Alastair Cook speaks: “When I got out I thought I was going to have another bat today. No disrespect to our lower order but it was difficult out there. I’ve got experience in the subcontintent and managed to find a method out there, but not all of them do. But it’s not about me today it’s about the proper Essex unit, we have a good time together, and Tendo [Ryan Ten Doeschate] has been absolutely brilliant as well as Anthony McGrath [the coach]. That’s why I carried on playing … “ then he breaks off to say, “I really want to go here because I don’t want to miss those celebrations.” He looks so much more casual, relaxed and chatty compared to the latter days of his England captaincy and career.

Tom Abell, the Somerset captain, has his say: “That middle session we gave ourselves a chance but it wasn’t meant to be. The supporters have been phenomenal, and the atmosphere was incredible when we got those wickets to get us ourselves a chance. Over a championship season the best team will prevail, so well done to Ryan and Essex. The square’s very dry here and we’ve got great spinners and we always felt if we had enough time there’d be chances. We’re gutted but have to say congratulations to Essex. We’re stull desperate for that championship win and it’ll certainly fuel the fire for next year

On Trescothick: “I don’t think any words can do him justice. It’s an impossible void to fill, a great player for Somerset and England,and more importantly, he’s a great person. A mentor to so many of us and great to have around.”

Ten Doeschate starts his own interview with a Trescothick tribute too before adding: “We got a bit lucky with the weather this week, and it’s been a long and tiring and testing season. The belief in the team, particularly the young guys, is second to none, Our cricket hasn’t always been pretty this year, but McGrath has been instrumental in getting the batting together and saying, ‘lads, we’re gonna score more runs this year even if it isn’t always pretty.’ Peter Siddle dragged the bowlers along, Cook and Porter, and it was good to see players like Aron Nijjar come on. And we can’t look too far past Mr Simon Harmer. He’s led the team with his attitude and he walks the walk. It’s been a monumental effort.”

5.29pm BST

So anyway, what a second half of the season Essex have enjoyed. They were more thereabouts than there in the early stages of the season, but came on strongly when the championship resumed in the closing weeks, despite not strengthening as some did (and losing Peter Siddle, who played his part early on). Simon Harmer was their undoubted player of the season, but he was well backed up with the seamers Sam Cook and Jamie Porter, and a batting order that has sufficient depth and reliability during a season of often harem-scaring batting everywhere and in all forms.

Somerset will be getting sick of being runners-up, and will see that skittling by Kyle Abbott in Southampton as the turning point for them, but they won a trophy too this term, and remain one of our most admirable county sides. One who, like Essex, have been cut out of the Hundred – so these two carving up the honours this season feels like delicious karma.

5.24pm BST

They let Trescothick walk off in front of all the others. The great Somerset opener waves his cap to all corners of the ground, and is given a parade in by the entire Essex team. Before the plaudits for Essex begin in earnest, let’s salute this wonderful cricketer, and pioneering player off the field as well.

5.22pm BST

The teams shake hands on a draw! Essex are champions!

Make that no minutes to go. The teams agree to call it quits. Essex have their second title in three years, and their second trophy this season.

5.21pm BST

18th over: Essex 45-1 (A Cook 30, Westley 1) target 63. A grubber from Van der Merwe deflects off Cook’s pads, beats a rusty Trescothick at leg slip and goes for four leg byes. A clip to deep midwicket brings another single. For what it’s worth, TV replays suggest Cook had another let-off in the previous over, when rapped in front by Bess. He’s had a charmed life today.

Ten minutes to go, 18 needed. Or nine wickets.

5.17pm BST

17th over: Essex 40-1 (A Cook 29, Westley 1) target 63. Aw, here’s lovely. Somerset signal their concession of the title by subbing on Marcus Trescothick, who gets a rousing reception from the whole ground, and his aura brings a wicket, Browne edging Bess to slip. Westley is off the mark with a single.

Leicestershire and Lancashire have shaken hands on a draw, which means, fittingly, that this is the only match of the 2019 English and Welsh cricket season still going.

5.14pm BST

Wicket! Browne c Vijay b Bess 10, Essex 38-1

Marcus Trescothick comes on as sub and his very presence conjures a wicket, as a teasing Bess delivery finds Browne’s edge and Vijay at slip does the rest.

5.12pm BST

16th over: Essex 38-0 (Browne 10, A Cook 28) target 63. Chants of “Campeones” fill the air as Browne drives Van der Merwe square on the offside for four. Go for the win lads. Go crazy. It’s in the bag now. A first double for the county since 1985’s John Player League/Natwest Trophy double (both won with last-over heartstoppers).

Updated at 5.12pm BST

5.08pm BST

15th over: Essex 33-0 (Browne 5, A Cook 28) target 63. A change of ends for Bess, who replaces Leach and turns one off-break sharply past Browne, who responds by clipping firmly to leg for one.

Marcus Trescothick is pacing the boundary, edgily, on drinks duty. How we’ll miss him.

Updated at 5.10pm BST

5.06pm BST

14th over: Essex 32-0 (Browne 4, A Cook 28) target 63. A firm clip from Cook in front of square off Van der Merwe brings three. Go on Sir Al, go for the win. I’ve seen him get a T20 hundred before (one of my claims to fame). Van der Merwe changes to round the wicket for Browne, who adds one more to the score by rocking back and turning it to leg. Somerset’s bowlers need a right-hander in.

5.02pm BST

13th over: Essex 28-0 (Browne 3, Cook 25) target 63. The previous over’s run glut hasn’t altered Somerset’s field placings. There are four men close in on the legside and two on the off, plus the keeper. Browne is unfazed though, and even tries to hit out when a rare full toss is sent his way, which he only clobbers straight to mid-on. No run.

4.59pm BST

12th over: Essex 28-0 (Browne 3, Cook 25) target 63. Van der Merwe is brought into the attack, as fielders continue to swarm round the bat. Of course every nudge, squirt and push that beats them brings runs, and Cook gets two more on the legside with no more than a simple prod. He’s playing with a record-breaker’s authority and pulls two short-ish deliveries to the square leg boundary for four. The last ball of the over is excellent though, pushed through quicker and Cook pushes forward off the inside edge and it falls agonisingly short of silly point.

In one over, the dial has moved again, and an Essex victory has loomed into view, as a Somerset one recedes.

4.55pm BST

11th over: Essex 18-0 (Browne 3, Cook 15) target 63. Leach isn’t going to die wondering when it comes to appealing. Every time he raps the pad he has a shout of some sort, as he does here after hitting Browne outside the line. He’s bowling well though, varying pace and turn, but so far these openers have been equal to him. Browne adds two more with a thick-edged drive square on the offside.

Apparently, the quickest any team has been bowled out was Derbyshire in 8.3 overs in 1939.

4.53pm BST

10th over: Essex 16-0 (Browne 1, Cook 15) target 63. Bess continues, as Van der Merwe warms up. He’s accurate enough, but not getting wickets yet. Cook picks up two twos with clips through the legside. Essex need 47 runs, Somerset need 10 wickets. Neither happening gives Essex the title, as does a victory for the visitors, obv.

4.49pm BST

9th over: Essex 12-0 (Browne 1, Cook 11) target 63. Aaron Nijjar has his pads on in the dressing room. So does Dan Lawrence. Is this telling us something about Essex’s batting strategy, or just that they’re all so anxious that they’ve strapped their pads on. Anyone who’s ever played low-level Sunday cricket on bobbly surfaces knows that feeling. Cook’s above all that though, and he drives Leach handsomely through the covers for four, adding one more by coolly rocking back and turning the ball to square leg.

A minimum of 10 overs remain, as do 41 minutes.

4.46pm BST

8th over: Essex 7-0 (Browne 1, Cook 6) target 63. Bess troubles Cook with one that’s a good full length, keeps low, and pings past his outside-edge. The knighted one then calmly adds a single with a clip through midwicket. Bess then bothers Browne with a similar ball to that which vexed Cook at the start of the over, but doesn’t find an edge. Essex have batted with reasonable composure so far – but I said that in the first innings, and then look what happened.

4.42pm BST

7th over: Essex 5-0 (Browne 1 Cook 5) target 63. Cook plants his front foot forward and pads up outside the line of off to Leach, who responds with an understandably overambitious appeal. Cook takes a flicked single, and Browne plays out the over well. They’re absolutely rattling through these overs, but no point doing that if you’re not going to get anyone out.

4.40pm BST

6th over: Essex 5-0 (Browne 1 Cook 4) target 63. Bess finds some more extravagant turn away from the left-handed Browne, who leaves well. He’s not, yet, looking as threatening as Van der Marwe did with the older ball an hour or so ago, and Essex will – anxiously, tentatively - be pleased to see another over go by without a wicket.

4.37pm BST

5th over: Essex 5-0 (Browne 1 Cook 4) target 63. Cooke is off the mark with a flick down to fine leg for four, and then sees out the over. Dot balls are all golden balls to Essex at the moment.

“It strikes me that Esssex have tottaly lost the plot here,” thunders John Withington. “Missed a great chance to attack with the field all around the bat in the first innings. With wickets tumbling it was the obvious thing to do to seek to close the gap and close the game out. But now, sending Cook and Brown out to block out they’re effectively inviting Somerset to bowl 20 overs at them. They should have had an early dash and kept Cook back to block out later if needed. The pitch is a joke of a spinners’ dream so why would you simply play to the opponent’s strength.”

I half-agree but it’s easier said than done, on this pitch, and against this attack.

4.34pm BST

4th over: Essex 1-0 (Browne 1 Cook 0) target 63. Bess bamboozles Browne with a lovely leg-break past the left-hander in a tidy over that’s a maiden. Essex showing no sign of going for the target so far, though they’ve not been given a chance to thanks to some fine bowling.

“It’s been an epic summer, no matter what the result of this match is,” trills Abhijato Sensarma, perhaps this season’s most prolific OBO emailer-iner. “What a time to be alive; what a conclusion to be witnessing! If there’s one thing the season’s taught us, it’s that it’s not over till it’s over ... Fasten your seatbelts, folks. Let’s get ready for one last ride.”

4.31pm BST

3rd over: Essex 1-0 (Browne 1 Cook 0) target 63. Essex are on their way! Browne calmly pushes Leach away through the legside for a single. Then a big appeal for a catch off the glove at short leg but umpire Wharf turns it down; it’s off pad, I think.

We’re into the last hour – a minimum of 16 overs will now ensue.

4.28pm BST

2nd over: Essex 0-0 (Browne 0 Cook 0) target 63. Somerset opt for an all-spin new-ball attack as we reach Peak Ciderabad. Bess it is who gets his first bowl for a while, pushing them through at a fair old pace to Cook, who’s getting forward confidently, though pushing hard at the ball served Essex poorly in their first-innings collapse. Another maiden.

4.25pm BST

1st over: Essex 0-0 (Browne O Cook 0) target 63. Boozy chants of “Somerset la, la, la” fill the air at a more-than-half-full looking Taunton (worth piling down there now if you’re in the vicinity) as the home side take the field. Nick Browne and Alastair Cook are out there again, Leach has the ball in hand again. Men are crouched round the bat en masse again. And one of them nearly takes a catch! Browne nudges to short leg and a diving Vijay can’t grasp it in time. A fine maiden. What a sport this is. Ravaged by rain for most of its four days, it’s still capable of conjuring a tense, memorable finish.

“I know I will probably be seen as a cricket illiterate,” says Jack Baker-Merry, “and it is exactly what Somerset will be hoping for, but I would be tempted to go for runs if I were Essex, and try and get the 63 before Somerset can get the 10.” I’d love for them to do it that way – nerves of steel needed though.

4.16pm BST

Somerset forfeit their second innings, Essex need 63 to win!

As predicted, Somerset give their second dig a swerve, and invite Essex to chase 63 in the last hour or so. But given that they’ve just taken nine in 19 overs or so, it’s by no means safe for Essex now. Is this incredible cricket season going to have one last crazy twist?

4.14pm BST

Wicket! Wheater c Davies b Van der Merwe 12, Essex 141 all out.

68.2 overs: Essex 141 (Porter 0 not out), trail by 64. Wheater plays a trademark sweep off Van der Merwe for four, as Essex realise they now need runs to mitigate the menace of any Somerset first-innings lead. But then he’s gone, bottom-edging to Davies behind the stumps. It’s Van der Merwe’s fourth scalp. Somerset lead by 62

Updated at 4.16pm BST

4.12pm BST

68 overs: Essex 137-9 (Wheater 8, Porter 0), trail by 64. Nijjar, in his first first-class game for four years, is back in the pavilion after becoming Leach’s fourth victim. And Sam Cook is his fifth, first ball, with a fuller, quicker ball that the batsman never came close to picking. Jamie Porter survives the hat-trick ball, not without alarms, edging sharply to the very close gully but it goes through his hands. Essex have now lost eight wickets for 35 runs.

Updated at 4.12pm BST

4.10pm BST

Wicket! Cook b Leach 0, Essex 137-9

Leach is on a hat-trick, clattering little chef’s stumps first ball. What are we seeing here?

4.08pm BST

Wicket! Nijjar lbw b Leach 2, Essex 137-8

Leach turns one into Nijjar, who misses and sees it rap him in front. Replays suggest it was turning so sharply it was perhaps just clipping leg.

4.06pm BST

67 overs: Essex 137-7 (Wheater 8, Nijjar 2), trail by 64. Wheater pushes at Van der Merwe and it squirts down past long-leg for four. A similarly unconvincing boundary comes in the same area when Wheater inside-edges an on-drive. It’s getting a bit gloomy overhead again.

“Interesting discussion on games based on cricket,” emails Simon Porter. “I remember buying a game called “crickcard” in the early 1960s - A game supposedly endorsed by one Trevor Bailey. It was a card game producing, runs, wickets and occasional dot balls. As an enthusiastic scorer in those days, the innings scores produced were highly unlikely. My brother and I developed this game into a more authentic scored game by using a deck of playing cards. Jokers were wicket taking balls, and therefore “appeals”, though depending on the quality and current performance of the batsman, they could be protected by the appearance of certain court cards after the appeal and so given not out. A much better and realistic score card could be produced, and many holidays were spent playing and working out season averages for many chosen players. teams. Is it very sad that I can remember it all so well?”

Yes, but in a good way. Be proud of yourself.

4.03pm BST

66 overs: Essex 129-7 (Wheater 0, Nijjar 2) Essex might have to think about trying to score some runs here, and Wheather can certainly do that, though he faces an ambitious lbw appeal from Leach after being struck akwardly on the pad to one that was going down leg. It yields a leg-bye. The left-handed Njjar then gets off the mark with an expansive on-drive/mow for tour.

4.01pm BST

65 overs: Essex 126-7 (Wheater 0) A double-wicket maiden for Van der Merwe, and batting suddenly looks even harder on this surface. The last hour starts at 4.30? How is this going to pan out?

Updated at 4.01pm BST

3.59pm BST

Wicket! Harmer c Vijay b Van der Merwe 0, Essex 126-7

Another one! Simon Harmer – Saturday’s batting hero – is flummoxed by one that spits up at him and can only fence it to Vijay at second slip. IS IT ON AGAIN?

3.58pm BST

Wicket! Westley c Gregory b Van der Merwe 36, Essex 126-6

Ooh, now what we have we here? The well-set Westley nudges an excellent delivery from Van der Merwe to Lewis Gregory to first slip. It was pushed right in on him, forcing him to play, and then turned to take the edge. Somerset now have a fighting chance of bowling Essex out at least and having another bat/forfeit.

Updated at 3.58pm BST

3.55pm BST

64 overs: Essex 126-5 (Westley 36, Wheater 0) Jack Leach picks up his third wicket, that of Ten Doeschate, and he nearly snares the new man, Adam Wheater, who pushes hard and edges to Murali Vijay at second slip, but it bounces in and out of his hands. A measure of just how close in the fielders are. Excellent over from Leach.

3.53pm BST

Wicket! Ten Doeschate c Abell b Leach 4, Essex 126-5

Another one for Leach, finding a thick edge from Ten Doeschate, who’s not looked particularly at ease, and Abell takes it at silly point.

3.51pm BST

63 overs: Essex 126-4 (Westley 36, Ten Doeschate 4) Ten Doeschate offers a slight chance to first slip after Van der Merwe turns one into him, but if drops short. An uppish cut for two that clears the infield ensues. By the way, in the only other game where they’ve not just cut their losses and gone to the bar, Leicestershire are 191-3 in their second innings against Lancashire, leading by 176.

3.48pm BST

62 overs: Essex 123-4 (Westley 36, Ten Doeschate 1) Ten Doeschate turns Leach round the corner to get off the mark with a single. They’re still crowding the bat, an expression of hope over realism at this stage, but it keeps the score down. Wonder if Essex will manage to get a batting point.

3.45pm BST

61 overs: Essex 122-4 (Westley 36, Ten Doeschate 0) So the final session of this glorious season gets under way, in bright sunshine. Van der Merwe continues, and Westley plays him well, mostly getting forward to meet the spin before it turns too extravagantly, as it has been doing all afternoon. And when Van der Merwe strays in his line, Westley can rock back and cut for four past point. Westley looks well placed to see this one home now.

3.41pm BST

Anyway, the players are back out.

3.38pm BST

Book cricket – it wasn’t just me being an oddball. Others were being oddballs too. Like David Blythe:

Just saw your mention of book cricket. Aged about 13 I found a version of this in an old Eagle annual I bought at a jumble sale. All the lower case vowels were dot balls, ‘m’ was bowled, ‘P’ run out, ‘V’ four runs etc. I added realism by giving players a chance to survive a wicket by rolling a dice, the score needed to stay in based on their career average versus the bowler’s average, and even had some rules I can’t remember now for speeding up the score in one day games. I replayed entire real life test series and fantasy games with my favourite players picked from around the world, with the scores recorded in exercise books for posterity.

Now that I’m just the wrong side of 50, I haven’t played the game properly for several decades, but often dream of starting up again when I retire. I still play a bit though. I played so often as a teenager that I can now remember what all the letters score. Many is the time a dull work presentation or subtitled foreign film has been livened up by playing a couple of test matches, totting up the scores in my head.

And James Falla:

Tom – I discovered “Book Cricket” as you call it in a vintage Eagle Annual when I was about 12. It dominated much of the next 20-odd years of my life, especially waiting for judgements in Magistrate’s Court as a young newspaper reporter!

For what it’s worth, this was my realistic alphabet

a – dot b – 1 c – 2 d - e – dot f – 1 g – dot h – 1 i – dot j – OUT k – OUT m – 4 n – dot o – dot

p – 1 q – OUT r – dot s – dot t – dot u – dot v – 4 w – 2 x – 6 y – 4 z – OUT

all capital letters – four if lower case is 0 or 1, six if lower case is worth any more runs

all punctuation – extras (calculated by various means)

This is predicated on test and county cricket, never tested on T20!

These people are my people. I’d like to think people play it using OBO entries too.

3.24pm BST

Tea, Essex 118-4

60 overs: Essex 118-4 (Westley 32, Ten Doeschate 0) A run! Westley pushes through the offside for a single off Leach, who offers a mid-range lbw appeal from the penultimate delivery after pushing one into Doeschate’s pads. Not out. And that’s tea. And it’s the end of what earlier in a game would have been a properly gripping and absorbing session – some composed batting, some raging turn and a brief clatter of wickets. But it’s all too late.

3.20pm BST

59 overs: Essex 117-4 (Westley 31, Ten Doeschate 0) Van der Merwe continues to the seasoned Ryan Ten Doeschate – there’s such a fine blend of promise and experience in this Essex side – though he’s done like a kipper from two that jag away, but it doesn’t take the edge. Good, testing over from the spinner. And they’re going to squeeze in another before tea.

Updated at 3.33pm BST

3.17pm BST

58 overs: Essex 117-4 (Westley 31, Ten Doeschate 0) Seven round the bat now, but not much in front of Westley who bunts a low full toss past the vacant mid-on area for four. Two more follow as another similar delivery is flicked to midwicket.

Updated at 3.22pm BST

3.13pm BST

57 overs: Essex 111-4 (Westley 25, Ten Doeschate 0) It’s been all spin today, though the briefest gander at this Cyderabad surface makes that entirely understandable. As Van der Merwe demonstrates by dismissing Bopara – that’s three wickets for nine. Just another 16 to go (including a brief thrash-batting interlude). Job’s a good’un.

3.11pm BST

Wicket! Bopara c Abell b Van der Merwe 1, Essex 111-4

Another one down. Bopara pops one up to silly point, where Abell takes the catch.

3.09pm BST

56 overs: Essex 111-3 (Westley 25, Bopara 1) Nice from Westley, leaning forward and smothering the spin to push away on the legside for two. Wonder if he’ll ever get an England chance again? There were technical flaws – playing to leg across the line – but technical strengths too, and he didn’t look hopelessly out of his depth.

3.06pm BST

55 overs: Essex 109-3 (Westley 23, Bopara 1) Bopara does well to keep out a grubber from Van der Merwe but is otherwise untroubled in an eventless maiden.

Going back to pencil cricket – and variants thereof – did anyone used to play ‘book cricket’, whereby you’d allocate an outcome (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, caught, bowled, lbw, runout, stumped) to each letter in the alphabet and then compile innings based on painstakingly going through a book or newspaper?

3.03pm BST

54 overs: Essex 109-3 (Westley 23, Bopara 1) It’s turning square at times here, which means Leach isn’t finding an edge with some of his rippers, but Westley sees out the maiden under the attentions of six close fielders.

3.01pm BST

53 overs: Essex 109-3 (Westley 23, Bopara 1) Van der Merwe is giving the batsmen something to think about too, finding some extravagant turn against Bopara, though he’s a seasoned campaigner, our Ravi, and does nowt rash.

2.59pm BST

52 overs: Essex 109-3 (Westley 23, Bopara 1) Leach rips another leg-break past Bopara’s outside edge, before the new man gets off the mark with a single. It’s a beautiful sunny day. “We wouldn’t have been here for a fourth day with this surface if the weather had stayed good,” says Dominic Cork in the commentary box. But then we’d have a different type of surface if it was sun-baked. Though this is Taunton.

2.55pm BST

51overs: Essex 108-3 (Westley 23, Bopara 0) Ooh! For all that Somerset have been unlucky with decisions today, there’s a suggestion that Overton might not have got his hands underneath that catch to dismiss Lawrence. Not easy to tell though. Six off this over, a two for Westley followed by a confident cover drive for four.

2.53pm BST

Wicket! Lawrence c Overton b Leach 0, Essex 102-3

50 overs: Essex 102-3 (Westley 17) Two in the over for Leach! New man Dan Lawrence edges his second ball low to Overton at slip, and these are deserved scalps.

2.50pm BST

Wicket! Cook c Banton b Leach 53

49.4 overs: Essex 102-2 (Westley 17) Leach has two slips, a silly point, a gully and a silly mid-off in for Westley, who still manages to squirt an edge past them for a single, bringing to the strike Cook, who brings up a fine 50 with a legside clip off a low full toss for four. The Essex fans in the crowd make themselves heard. Well played sir.

And then next ball – he’s gone, prodding off bat and pad to Tom Banton at silly mid-on

Updated at 2.52pm BST

2.46pm BST

49th over: Essex 97-1 (Westley 16, Cook 49) Another over featuring one run to Cook, from Van der Merwe. Westley gets one too.

“I think Peter Salmon is onto a winner,” says Kim Thonger of jazzing up our cricketing spin-off games. “But let’s make it a bit livelier. I’m thinking a cross between Its a Knockout, The Crystal Maze and Treasure Hunt. Anneka Rice could compere possibly with Henry Blofeld and Alan ‘Chatty Man’ Carr. I’d do the whole thing on ice if I had artistic control. Ben Stokes in a skintight leotard doing a triple falco ought to set even the most elderly ECB overlord’s pulse racing, hopefully creating a few vacancies on the steering committee.”

Updated at 2.49pm BST

2.44pm BST

48th over: Essex 95-1 (Westley 15, Cook 48) Leach continues, Cook continues to get ‘em in ones, so he should have his 50 in Leach’s next over. Then another big appeal, as a ripper from Leach jags from leg to off and beats Westley all ends up. No edge discerned by the umpire, replays suggest a possible glove/back-arm combo. Somerset have been unlucky today. Then an ultra-edge examination on Sky finds no nick and vindicates the umpire.

2.39pm BST

47th over: Essex 94-1 (Westley 15, Cook 47) Van der Merwe appeals for a feathered catch to the keeper down the legside against Cook, but the umpire rules that feather came there none. Somerset have a leg slip and a leg gully in for Cook but he managed to beat both to get a clipped single,

Updated at 2.41pm BST

45th over: Essex 92-1 (Westley 15, Cook 45) Thanks Tanya and greetings everyone, as Van der Merwe rattles through another over, yielding a solitary single.. There’s no lack of focus out there, as Somerset continue to crowd round the bat while the Essex pair, it must be said, have shown application and skill in seeing this out. As they surely will now. Somerset need 19 wickets in the next three hours or so.

2.32pm BST

44th over: Essex 91-1 (Westley 15, Cook 44) Bess has been very busy today, bowling unchanged from the Ian Botham end. On he rolls, dangerous, but without luck. Four tasty byes trickle away.

And that’s it from me, as I hand over to Tom Davies. A wonderful season; thanks to you all for your messages and emails. It’s been a lot of fun.

1.29pm BST

24th over: Essex 38-1 (Westley 1, Cook 15) Not quite sure what happened there sorry I was eating lemon cheese cake with Vic and they started a little early.

Lunch is being taken at Taunton

12.39pm BST

22nd over: Essex 35-1 (Westley 0, Cook 12) A precious wicket with the last ball of Bess’s over. Surely, surely, there is no time...

12.38pm BST

WICKET! Browne c Banton b Bess 18

Updated at 12.38pm BST

12.34pm BST

21st over: Essex 34-0 (Browne 18, Cook 12) And another maiden from Leach. Testing times for Cook and Browne.

12.33pm BST

A couple of lovely notes about pencil/dice cricket.

From Romeo:

I used to play the same game with a pair of commercially produced metal hexagonal bars which I expect my grandfather (who first taught me cricket) gave us. It was called ‘Howzat’.

After a while it became clear that it wasn’t that representative of actual cricket as the probability of a six or a wicket or a whatever didn’t match what I saw in International Cavaliers matches on BBC2 on
Sundays.

To remedy this, I then decided to cut out a circle of card, about four inches diameter (this is pre-decimal), and draw pie-chart sectors on it, a big one for a dot, a smaller one for a single, a much smaller one for
a four and a tiny one for a six. I did the same with the ‘how out’ possibilities (in a different-coloured crayon).

I then stuck a pin in the middle and then onto a board, spun the disc and as it fell against a mark on the board, played the game.

I used to score the matches in a proper scorebook, with made-up teams of my favourite players, and would often play entire Test series (usually England against Rest of the World.

I’d do this throughout the summer when it was raining. If it wasn’t, I’d be in the garden being bowled or tonked by my elder brother.”

And from Peter Salmon:

Nice to hear that Kim Thonger has got the pencils out. Great game, spent ours playing it in my exciting yoof. Quick question though, does he change the pencils depending on the format of the game? For 20/20 you only really need 1, 4, 4, 6, 6 and out. And is today the last time we’ll watch Sir Al bat?

I don’t think so unless you know something that I don’t...

12.29pm BST

19th over: Essex 34-0 (Browne 18, Cook 12) In front of me, the groundsmen are sitting by the wheel-on covers, just in case y’all. Two dogs stare each other out to the side of the Ondaatje stand. Leach spins in, tossing the ball high, then low, with the men round the bat close enough to advise on necessary nasal hair removal.

12.26pm BST

18th over: Essex 34-0 (Browne 18, Cook 12) Young Dom Bess, who spent a fair chunk of his season at Headingley, gets to finish off the season bowling in the title decider at Taunton. Hope he stays. Grubby-knee-ed, he bowls with barely a pause. Cook, a master at this stuff, muffles and nudges.

12.24pm BST

17th over: Essex 32-0 (Browne 18, Cook 10) The skies are bordering on black. Leach appeals for LBW against Browne but the umpires remain uninterested. Somerset are whizzing through these overs.

12.22pm BST

16th over: Essex 32-0 (Browne 18, Cook 10) Brown uses the full length of his limbs to stretch forward to muffle Bess’s spin. Just a single, but that matters not a bean. Somerset need 20 wickets.

12.20pm BST

15th over: Essex 31-0 (Browne 18, Cook 9) Leach, rubbing his left hand to keep feeling in those fingers, comes in off his seven-step run-up. Just one off the over. In the stands, fleeces are zipped to the chin.

12.17pm BST

14th over: Essex 30-0 (Browne 17, Cook 9) And so they try again. Dom Bess replaces Van der Merwe at the ITBotham stand. Bess, bowling in long sleeves, wheels in, lovely action. The pitch is an unpredictable as a yorkshire pudding. Cook sweeps for four.

12.13pm BST

David Lloyd writes:

Tanya, answering you call for emails, much was made at the start of the season about the new Dukes ball and how batsmen would be dominant because it would do less than the old one, so much so that the old ball was pressed into use for the Ashes. In practice there have been lots of games where the ball has been in the ascendant (and not just those in which Worcs were playing...). Has there been any comment from coaches/teams about the ball over the season? Will the same ball be used next year?

Thanks again for all your work over the summer. Makes keeping up with the CC so much fun.

This is true David, and the issue seems to have been largely forgotten about since. Hang on a minute, the players are coming back out!

The rain, it falls

And thank you to Andrew Cosgrove for clearing up the boundary dispute:

The change to the boundary law was relatively recent. It was not something that gradually changed, it will have been when the laws were revised in the last few years. The laws specifically used to say that if a fence or similar was used as the boundary marker, the ball had to clear the fence to be a six (striking the fence was a four), and that a fielder was permitted to lean on the fence in order to catch a ball landing beyond the fence. I have so far been unable to pinpoint when that revision to the laws were made, but I’m pretty sure it was some time this century.

He later pinpoints it:

The change was made in the 2000 revision of the laws compare
https://apps.lords.org/assets/Uploads/MCC-Laws-of-Cricket-2000-Code-6th-Edition-2016.pdf

With http://static.espncricinfo.com/db/ABOUT_CRICKET/LAWS/1980_CODE/LAW_19_BOUNDARIES.html
19.3 (c) A Fieldsman with ball in hand grounds any part of his person over a boundary fence or board. This allows the Fieldsman to touch or lean on or over a boundary fence or board in preventing a boundary.
Whereas in the updated law, 19.2 (c) (ii) For a fence, which includes any similar object in contact with the ground but with a flat surface projecting above the ground, the boundary edge will be the base line of the fence.

We’re about to start here at Taunton, though the sky is looking rather ominous to the south-west.

Play will resume at Taunton at noon

“As my hopes of glory fade in the rain clouds I’m distracting myself by playing Somerset v Essex using two hexagonal pencils. I haven’t done this since childhood in the late 60s but it seems a reasonable way to decide the Championship.

“Then roll it.

“The second pencil, marked with four methods of dismissal, B, C, RUN OUT, or LBW comes into play when the first pencil is rolled and ends with the Out side uppermost. The other two sides on the second pencil are NO BALL and WIDE

11.23am BST

“As a Notts fan I might be biased but watching the video in the article it’s incredible that the catch up against the hoardings (Hadlee caught out) was given out with the fielder leaning on the hoardings as he takes it - and also amazing that the hoardings were the boundary apparently.”

Ollie Pope scored a wonderful hundred for Surrey against Notts, backed up by a more reserved effort by Scott Borthwick; Ben Charlesworth and Graeme van Buuren advanced the score for Gloucestershire; Lancashire were bowled out for 170 in a vain-glorious attempt to lose their first match of the season against wooden-spoonists Leicestershire; and Harvey Hosein and Leus du Plooy both scored fifties for Derby.

8.59am BST

One Final Good Morning

on this, the last day of the 2019 county season. Taunton has pulled up her socks and is looking glorious for the occasion, with blue skies and people tripping coatless across the light turquoise wrought iron bridge over the river on their way to the ground. The yew trees in St James’ churchyard stand majestic, but the last summer fuchsias are moulding, the buddleia are leggy and autumn leaves have blown against the walls of the church. It is time.

First things first, it isn’t raining, but it did, heavily, during the night. The groundstaff are busy, zipping about on their incredible machines, but the outfield is damp - yesterday so damp that water was coming up through the surface on the pavilion side of the ground

Hopes of Somerset winning the first Championship in their history had all but drained away with yesterday’s washout. But one man still believes, Andy Hurry, Somerset’s director of cricket, whose optimism produced one of the stranger press conferences of the season last night.

“Our challenge has become stiffer, but having displayed courage, conviction and belief all season, we are not going to lose it overnight.We have put too much on the line for too long to wave the white flag. That’s not what we are about. Tomorrow is about giving 100 per cent and, whatever happens, putting down a marker for next year.”

“I have total belief in our players and staff. This summer there has been some amazing cricket, with huge twists and turns. Anything can happen and we have to keep believing.”

So there you go - can there possibly be one final twist in this crazy-love summer?

fields.bodyText: Well, it’s not easy to sum up this season in a few words. It’s been a blast, from T20 to World Cups to Ashes to a championship that went to the wire, between its two best teams who even amid ridiculous autumn weather managed to rustle us up a finish today with some twists and turns, particularly turns on a textbook Ciderabad pitch. Congrats Essex, commiserations Somerset, and thanks to everyone including you, our readers, for a wonderful long summer of cricket. See you again soon. Bye. Alastair Cook speaks: “When I got out I thought I was going to have another bat today. No disrespect to our lower order but it was difficult out there. I’ve got experience in the subcontintent and managed to find a method out there, but not all of them do. But it’s not about me today it’s about the proper Essex unit, we have a good time together, and Tendo [Ryan Ten Doeschate] has been absolutely brilliant as well as Anthony McGrath [the coach]. That’s why I carried on playing … “ then he breaks off to say, “I really want to go here because I don’t want to miss those celebrations.” He looks so much more casual, relaxed and chatty compared to the latter days of his England captaincy and career. Tom Abell, the Somerset captain, has his say: “That middle session we gave ourselves a chance but it wasn’t meant to be. The supporters have been phenomenal, and the atmosphere was incredible when we got those wickets to get us ourselves a chance. Over a championship season the best team will prevail, so well done to Ryan and Essex. The square’s very dry here and we’ve got great spinners and we always felt if we had enough time there’d be chances. We’re gutted but have to say congratulations to Essex. We’re stull desperate for that championship win and it’ll certainly fuel the fire for next year On Trescothick: “I don’t think any words can do him justice. It’s an impossible void to fill, a great player for Somerset and England,and more importantly, he’s a great person. A mentor to so many of us and great to have around.” Ten Doeschate starts his own interview with a Trescothick tribute too before adding: “We got a bit lucky with the weather this week, and it’s been a long and tiring and testing season. The belief in the team, particularly the young guys, is second to none, Our cricket hasn’t always been pretty this year, but McGrath has been instrumental in getting the batting together and saying, ‘lads, we’re gonna score more runs this year even if it isn’t always pretty.’ Peter Siddle dragged the bowlers along, Cook and Porter, and it was good to see players like Aron Nijjar come on. And we can’t look too far past Mr Simon Harmer. He’s led the team with his attitude and he walks the walk. It’s been a monumental effort.” So anyway, what a second half of the season Essex have enjoyed. They were more thereabouts than there in the early stages of the season, but came on strongly when the championship resumed in the closing weeks, despite not strengthening as some did (and losing Peter Siddle, who played his part early on). Simon Harmer was their undoubted player of the season, but he was well backed up with the seamers Sam Cook and Jamie Porter, and a batting order that has sufficient depth and reliability during a season of often harem-scaring batting everywhere and in all forms. Somerset will be getting sick of being runners-up, and will see that skittling by Kyle Abbott in Southampton as the turning point for them, but they won a trophy too this term, and remain one of our most admirable county sides. One who, like Essex, have been cut out of the Hundred – so these two carving up the honours this season feels like delicious karma. They let Trescothick walk off in front of all the others. The great Somerset opener waves his cap to all corners of the ground, and is given a parade in by the entire Essex team. Before the plaudits for Essex begin in earnest, let’s salute this wonderful cricketer, and pioneering player off the field as well. Make that no minutes to go. The teams agree to call it quits. Essex have their second title in three years, and their second trophy this season. 18th over: Essex 45-1 (A Cook 30, Westley 1) target 63. A grubber from Van der Merwe deflects off Cook’s pads, beats a rusty Trescothick at leg slip and goes for four leg byes. A clip to deep midwicket brings another single. For what it’s worth, TV replays suggest Cook had another let-off in the previous over, when rapped in front by Bess. He’s had a charmed life today. Ten minutes to go, 18 needed. Or nine wickets. 17th over: Essex 40-1 (A Cook 29, Westley 1) target 63. Aw, here’s lovely. Somerset signal their concession of the title by subbing on Marcus Trescothick, who gets a rousing reception from the whole ground, and his aura brings a wicket, Browne edging Bess to slip. Westley is off the mark with a single. Leicestershire and Lancashire have shaken hands on a draw, which means, fittingly, that this is the only match of the 2019 English and Welsh cricket season still going. Marcus Trescothick comes on as sub and his very presence conjures a wicket, as a teasing Bess delivery finds Browne’s edge and Vijay at slip does the rest. 16th over: Essex 38-0 (Browne 10, A Cook 28) target 63. Chants of “Campeones” fill the air as Browne drives Van der Merwe square on the offside for four. Go for the win lads. Go crazy. It’s in the bag now. A first double for the county since 1985’s John Player League/Natwest Trophy double (both won with last-over heartstoppers). 15th over: Essex 33-0 (Browne 5, A Cook 28) target 63. Somerset are whizzing through these overs. 16th over: Essex 32-0 (Browne 18, Cook 10) Brown uses the full length of his limbs to stretch forward to muffle Bess’s spin. Just a single, but that matters not a bean. Somerset need 20 wickets. 15th over: Essex 31-0 (Browne 18, Cook 9) Leach, rubbing his left hand to keep feeling in those fingers, comes in off his seven-step run-up. Just one off the over. In the stands, fleeces are zipped to the chin. 14th over: Essex 30-0 (Browne 17, Cook 9) And so they try again. Dom Bess replaces Van der Merwe at the ITBotham stand. Bess, bowling in long sleeves, wheels in, lovely action. The pitch is an unpredictable as a yorkshire pudding. Cook sweeps for four. And that might well be that. It looked pretty tricky out there to bat, breadcrumbs for what might have been. David Lloyd writes: Tanya, answering you call for emails, much was made at the start of the season about the new Dukes ball and how batsmen would be dominant because it would do less than the old one, so much so that the old ball was pressed into use for the Ashes. In practice there have been lots of games where the ball has been in the ascendant (and not just those in which Worcs were playing...). Has there been any comment from coaches/teams about the ball over the season? Will the same ball be used next year? Thanks again for all your work over the summer. Makes keeping up with the CC so much fun. This is true David, and the issue seems to have been largely forgotten about since. Hang on a minute, the players are coming back out! And the players come off. 13th over: Essex 25-0 (Browne 16, Cook 5) And as Jack Leach takes the ball from the pavilion end, the floodlights come on. Alastair Cook goes back on his stumps and oooooh! a huge appeal for lbw to one that spun sharply, but the umpire is not impressed. And I’m afraid the anoraks are coming on again. 12th over: Essex 25-0 (Browne 16, Cook 5) Just to confirm that they will be taking lunch at one. Left-armer van der Merwe takes the ball from the Sir Ian Botham Stand end, Browne prods forward, and forward again. A maiden. And thank you to Andrew Cosgrove for clearing up the boundary dispute: The change to the boundary law was relatively recent. It was not something that gradually changed, it will have been when the laws were revised in the last few years. The laws specifically used to say that if a fence or similar was used as the boundary marker, the ball had to clear the fence to be a six (striking the fence was a four), and that a fielder was permitted to lean on the fence in order to catch a ball landing beyond the fence. I have so far been unable to pinpoint when that revision to the laws were made, but I’m pretty sure it was some time this century. He later pinpoints it: The change was made in the 2000 revision of the laws compare https://apps.lords.org/assets/Uploads/MCC-Laws-of-Cricket-2000-Code-6th-Edition-2016.pdf With http://static.espncricinfo.com/db/ABOUT_CRICKET/LAWS/1980_CODE/LAW_19_BOUNDARIES.html 19.3 (c) A Fieldsman with ball in hand grounds any part of his person over a boundary fence or board. This allows the Fieldsman to touch or lean on or over a boundary fence or board in preventing a boundary. Whereas in the updated law, 19.2 (c) (ii) For a fence, which includes any similar object in contact with the ground but with a flat surface projecting above the ground, the boundary edge will be the base line of the fence. We’re about to start here at Taunton, though the sky is looking rather ominous to the south-west. This is rather lovely. If there is no more rain... In defiance of the rain, Kim Thonger is deciding the Championship with his pencil case. “As my hopes of glory fade in the rain clouds I’m distracting myself by playing Somerset v Essex using two hexagonal pencils. I haven’t done this since childhood in the late 60s but it seems a reasonable way to decide the Championship. “For those unfamiliar with the game, you simply mark each side of the first pencil with 1,2,3,4,6,Out “Then roll it. “The second pencil, marked with four methods of dismissal, B, C, RUN OUT, or LBW comes into play when the first pencil is rolled and ends with the Out side uppermost. The other two sides on the second pencil are NO BALL and WIDE “These days I suppose a third pencil could be added to decide the outcome of reviews using DRS “A rudimentary scorecard is required. The back page of an arithmetic exercise book always worked well. “Somerset are currently romping to what looks like an innings victory. This is obviously what would have happened had the weather gods not frowned upon us.” “Thanks for the coverage this season and thanks for the link to the story about the 1984 season” writes Nick Butler. [It’s a pleasure!] “As a Notts fan I might be biased but watching the video in the article it’s incredible that the catch up against the hoardings (Hadlee caught out) was given out with the fielder leaning on the hoardings as he takes it - and also amazing that the hoardings were the boundary apparently.” It is! I’ve asked around the press box and no-one can remember when that changed, when the hoardings became disqualifiers. One of those things that just slowly segued perhaps? There is no play yet today. Anywhere. Do send me an email or two. Some succour for the south west. This is a timely, and super read, by Steve Pye. A note, from Sam Aldred in Auckland: “The Taunton all rounders competition must feel like a long time ago.” [NB very funny but where’s my birthday card? It was ‘in the post’ in February] Hampshire twist the knife, announcing a new three-year contract with their dream-crusher Kyle Abbott. “I can’t speak highly enough of Kyle,” said Hampshire’s director of cricket Giles White. “He has once again shown what a valuable asset he is to the team. He continually puts in match-winning contributions; he is a great role model for the younger players and he shows a great passion for playing for the club. For all these reasons we are delighted he will be with us for the long-term.” Abbot has pocketed more than 50 Championship wickets in each of the last three years. In the last round his 17-86 destroyed Somerset and left them with a tricky 12 point deficit going into this round, which then became impossible to overhaul due to rain. . And so it ends. There will be no play before lunch at Edgbaston, there will be an inspection at 10.30 at Grace Road, it is raining at Lord’s and is damp at The Oval. No news yet from Hove. And, just in, a further inspection at 11.30 here at Taunton. But here are the nominations for the PCA young players of the year.. Here’s to a happy man in his office. Time for doughnuts all round Steve? They’ve called it a day at Canterbury for Kent v Hampshire, at Bristol, now both sides are safely promoted, as well as at The Riverside. And here at Taunton, the cover are back on again. With the match at The Riverside between Glamorgan and Durham being abandoned after heavy overnight rain, Gloucestershire and Northamptonshire will join Lancashire in Division One next year. Congratulations! After toast and coffee at the Bakery at Riverside Coffee Shop (highly recommended), I’m back at the ground where Somerset are playing football with a linesman in full kit. But I’m afraid to say the sky is now looking very grey. Hey-ho, but this is a lovely interview, with Darren Stevens. Round the grounds, Northants and Gloucestershire are nearly guaranteed Division One cricket next season, as chasers Glamorgan’s game against Durham has failed to get more than a few steps off the starting blocks. As well as players examining their palms at Taunton, there was no play at all yesterday at Canterbury, Edgbaston, The Riverside or Hove. Ollie Pope scored a wonderful hundred for Surrey against Notts, backed up by a more reserved effort by Scott Borthwick; Ben Charlesworth and Graeme van Buuren advanced the score for Gloucestershire; Lancashire were bowled out for 170 in a vain-glorious attempt to lose their first match of the season against wooden-spoonists Leicestershire; and Harvey Hosein and Leus du Plooy both scored fifties for Derby. on this, the last day of the 2019 county season. Taunton has pulled up her socks and is looking glorious for the occasion, with blue skies and people tripping coatless across the light turquoise wrought iron bridge over the river on their way to the ground. The yew trees in St James’ churchyard stand majestic, but the last summer fuchsias are moulding, the buddleia are leggy and autumn leaves have blown against the walls of the church. It is time. First things first, it isn’t raining, but it did, heavily, during the night. The groundstaff are busy, zipping about on their incredible machines, but the outfield is damp - yesterday so damp that water was coming up through the surface on the pavilion side of the ground Hopes of Somerset winning the first Championship in their history had all but drained away with yesterday’s washout. But one man still believes, Andy Hurry, Somerset’s director of cricket, whose optimism produced one of the stranger press conferences of the season last night. “Our challenge has become stiffer, but having displayed courage, conviction and belief all season, we are not going to lose it overnight.We have put too much on the line for too long to wave the white flag. That’s not what we are about. Tomorrow is about giving 100 per cent and, whatever happens, putting down a marker for next year.” “I have total belief in our players and staff. This summer there has been some amazing cricket, with huge twists and turns. Anything can happen and we have to keep believing.” So there you go - can there possibly be one final twist in this crazy-love summer?
fields.bylineHtml: Tanya Aldred at Taunton (earlier) and Tom Davies (later)

webTitle: ‘I just wanted to sing’ – Elizabeth Llewellyn’s unorthodox journey to becoming a soprano

fields.headline: ‘I just wanted to sing’ – Elizabeth Llewellyn’s unorthodox journey to becoming a soprano
fields.standfirst: Despite an illness forcing a decade-long hiatus, the singer’s career has moved from strength to strength. She tells Tshepo Mokoena about her path into opera
fields.trailText: Despite an illness forcing a decade-long hiatus, the singer’s career has moved from strength to strength. She tells Tshepo Mokoena about her path into opera
fields.body:
Some of us are destined to end up on a particular path, no matter what obstacles life may hurl in the way. Opera singer Elizabeth Llewellyn is one of those people. The 46-year-old’s unorthodox journey from her childhood in south London to breathtaking stage and concert performances around the world is testament to how there’s no singular route into classical music.

At first glance, her story starts in a way you might expect, with a piqued childhood interest. Aged 10, Llewellyn began the piano lessons that would form the bedrock of her musical education. “I remember my piano teacher gave me a cassette of violinist Nigel Kennedy, playing a version of Vivaldi’s Four Seasons,” she says, speaking on a busy day in New York between rehearsals for an upcoming lead role in Porgy and Bess.

As a child born to Jamaican parents and growing up in the 1980s, a career in opera may not have been an obvious choice. But Llewellyn has never been the type to follow the crowd.

She quickly became hooked on classical music. “When you’re a child, you tend to get involved in whatever’s around you. So when you’re learning an instrument, you absorb what your teacher feeds you.” In her case, that entailed taking in classical music of all sorts, during lessons that stretched for hours at a time on Saturday afternoons. But that seemingly ordinary foray into music would start to divert for Llewellyn.

  • Llewellyn as Bess (left) and Manon Lescaut

Unlike many of her professional opera peers, she took a 10-year detour at the start of her 20s, when an inexplicable illness – akin to a series of incessant, persistent colds – forced her to leave Manchester’s prestigious Royal Northern College of Music and stop singing altogether. After working in everything from IT and telecoms to the travel industry, Llewellyn wound up back where she belonged: singing, for rapturous audiences. She debuted professionally as Mimì in La Bohème with the English National Opera in 2010, and will sing as part of a BBC Symphony Orchestra and Chorus performance in March 2020.

Looking back, Llewellyn can trace her love for music from piano to an interest buoyed by “choirs, then learning the violin when I was about 13. I was involved in orchestra, and string orchestra, the string quartet …” and as her voice trails off you wonder how she managed to fit it all in around school itself. After being accepted to the Royal Northern College of Music, however, her entire perspective changed. “I was used to playing piano concertos with the school orchestra, singing solos in concerts,” she remembers fondly. “And then … you get to music college. And you realise you haven’t got any technique; you’re not actually very good compared to everyone else around you” – and now she chuckles at the memory. “That first year, for me, was a bit of a horror,” a moment when she stopped and thought: “Oh my goodness, I’m really not that good am I?”

  • Performing with the BBC Symphony Orchestra

Although she felt she had much to learn, Llewellyn’s always deployed an emotional heft in her singing. It’s part of the reason why, after several years away from music, a director of a local, amateur operatic music group noticed her talent and suggested she pursue opera with more commitment. After all, as she recalls: “Even when I applied for music college, I don’t think I wanted to be ‘an opera singer’. I just wanted to sing.”

Though she’d not been immersed in opera from infancy – as is a more common background – she felt an undeniable compulsion to sing. And her time away from music proved pivotal to enriching her vocal delivery. She gained the life experience to pour into her work that she would otherwise have lacked, she thinks, had she leapt into the professional world as a teen.

“Although I wouldn’t have chosen for things to have worked out that way,” she says, referencing the mysterious illness that derailed her, “I think I benefited from having that time away from the classical music scene. For singers, I think it’s really important to grow up emotionally and take time to absorb the world around you, and what it means to be human.” Though she half-jokes that “some of the plots of operas are fairly ridiculous”, she notes that “they are all rooted in real stories”.

Related: Elgar to Mahler: seven pieces of classical music to help you relax into the moment

And so she’s looking forward to digging into some of that emotive and narrative flair as one of four soloists when Richard Farnes conducts Beethoven’s Missa solemnis, in March next year. “Vocally, it’s a really interesting piece to prepare for.” She considers it “a bit more ‘full-fat’ than, say, Mozart in terms of vocal approach”. Even listening to her describe the piece’s “muscularity” it’s clear that a passion like hers has the capacity to turn someone who normally avoids classical music into one willing to experience some, live.

Llewellyn knows people may critique her, or look to knock her unusual route to success. But she’s adamant about the power of self-belief – after all, it got her this far. “You’ve got to know that your voice and your way of looking at the world, and your approach, is just as valid as the next person’s,” she says. “Your uniqueness and the thing that makes you you is really interesting. You can get pulled in lots of directions otherwise, and have no voice – and that’s death for an artist.” Chances are, even if others tried to pull her to and fro, Llewellyn would land on her feet. The stage is her home.

Listen to Elizabeth Llewellyn live as she joins three other stunning soloists and conductor Richard Farnes for Beethoven’s Missa solemnis

webTitle: From concert hall to club: classical music has a new home

fields.headline: From concert hall to club: classical music has a new home
fields.standfirst: Stephen Connolly looks at how the traditional music form is breaking boundaries and seeking out new audiences, by defying stereotypes and bending genres
fields.trailText: Stephen Connolly looks at how the traditional music form is breaking boundaries and seeking out new audiences, by defying stereotypes and bending genres
fields.body:
Classical music is often incorrectly assumed to be one-dimensional, but a wave of musicians are pushing the music beyond its traditional boundaries and into spaces you might not expect to hear it. Championing this development is Elizabeth Alker (presenter of BBC Radio 3’s alt-classical show, Unclassified). She says: “There are plenty of people working to take classical music out of the concert hall and to new audiences in clubs and warehouse venues. Groups like the Manchester Collective or Nonclassical, they’re bold and ambitious and they’re extremely passionate about the music and giving audiences the opportunity to hear it. It’s pretty radical to stage a work like Schoenberg’s Pierrot Lunaire in a marketplace in Hull!”

Radical as it may be, such events are part of a growing movement that’s creating environments for mixed audiences of musical purists and the culturally curious to encounter classical music in unexpected ways. For the composer Gabriel Prokofiev, from a renowned classical family and the disruptor-founder of the Nonclassical club night, the creation of open, relatable events is needed to break down the walls between DJs and dinner jackets. “It’s all part of the process of classical music catching up with contemporary lifestyles,” he says. “Classical music is stuck in a bubble and most of the people involved don’t necessarily realise they’re in a bubble – they just love the music, it works for them, but that’s a tradition and a way of presenting the music that doesn’t really fit with modern ways of living.”

Alker, herself a clarinettist by training, agrees that removing traditional boundaries is key to delivering new experiences. “I think, sometimes, the way classical music is presented can seem a bit more formal than contemporary audiences are used to,” she says. “A couple of years ago, I worked on a series of concerts called the Red Brick Sessions with the BBC Philharmonic. We had live scrolling programme notes, the bar was open, and we had an interval discussion that was very permissive and open. It felt relaxed and fun, but there was still a reverence for and enjoyment of the music. It was just rowdier than a lot of classical concerts. I’m in favour of a bit more rowdiness.”

The BBC’s Beyond Boundaries series of concerts does as the title suggests, pushing the notion of a classical concert beyond what is usually associated with the genre. While rowdy may not be the first adjective that springs to mind with this series, unconventional certainly does. Concerts feature non-classical elements such as music from video games, spoken word and pop and jazz. As part of this series, conductor Jules Buckley and singer-songwriter Lianne La Havas will join the BBC Symphony Orchestra on 28 February.

What’s clear is that across the spectrum of those working to change classical music’s perception among modern audiences, the power and relevance of the music itself is undiminished. DJ and electronic musician Max Cooper has repeatedly explored the connections between computers and conductors and, for him, classical music’s “melodic richness stays relevant centuries later”.

For Cooper, there’s a special resonance in the work of minimalist composers such as Philip Glass, which “pre-empts the core principles of modern electronic music in terms of its focus on loops, repetition, syncopation and complexity”. Whether it’s classical or electronic, old or new, it is, he thinks, “all one big melting pot of patterns”, with “more parallels than differences”.

Related: Leave the tuxedo at home: classical music myths explored

For Prokofiev too, his own music, which is as indebted to grime and hip-hop as it is to traditional orchestration, is composed as a conduit for younger people to experience something he thinks remains vital. “In a way,” he says, “classical is more relevant than ever. It takes you away from the more high-speed lifestyles we have; the screen-swiping, quick fix of modern technology.” And the creation of new events and forms of music that can produce a dialogue between classical and modern is ultimately about community: “You sit there and you’ve got direct interaction with human beings in the room creating really beautiful music that can give you a different, more concentrated, immersive experience.”

Alker sees the upcoming Unclassified Live concerts as a good place to start for those wanting to get a view into this crossover world of baritones and bars. The series is, she reveals, “our new collaboration with the BBC Concert Orchestra, Southbank Sinfonia, the Queen Elizabeth Hall at the Southbank and the conductor André de Ridder. We’ve chosen artists I play on my Radio 3 show to either write new music or have existing work arranged for the orchestras.”

The next season of events, which starts in September and runs throughout 2020, “includes electronic artists such as Daniel Avery, Tim Hecker and Darkstar, alongside composers such as Anna Meredith, Caroline Shaw and Nicole Lizée”. They’ve all been chosen, she says, because “they all make such original and brilliant music, and the BBC Concert Orchestra and Southbank Sinfonia are such flexible and innovative groups. They all embody Unclassified’s interest in how ancient practices and instrumental groups collide with new techniques and sounds.”

Even for the seasoned presenter, it feels like a leap into new and exciting territory: “I cannot wait to hear how it sounds with a full orchestra, and to see their fans, who might not be familiar with orchestral music, experience the emotive power of an ensemble that size. This isn’t going to be a case of sticking cheesy strings on music, but of creating unusual textures, surprising sounds and dynamic, collaborative, live performances for inquisitive music lovers.”

See the full list of upcoming concerts in the BBC’s Beyond Boundaries series

webTitle: Leave the tuxedo at home: classical music myths explored

fields.headline: Leave the tuxedo at home: classical music myths explored
fields.standfirst: Don’t get caught up in outdated beliefs – classical music offers something for everyone, says Jonathan Lennie
fields.trailText: Don’t get caught up in outdated beliefs – classical music offers something for everyone, says Jonathan Lennie
fields.body:
Despite the best efforts of orchestras and opera companies to attract a new and younger audience, some classical music myths still abound. Somehow, there persists an idea that classical concerts are very formal events in which people in tuxedos and ballgowns buy very expensive tickets to hear ancient, irrelevant music, performed by ageing men dressed like they are from the 19th century. And, even if you did manage to pass the classical music quiz to get in, they would soon spot your inappropriate behaviour and, not being an expert, you would have no idea what is going on, right? Wrong. None of that is true, of course.

Trainers allowed
Modern audiences come in all shapes and sizes, and are as likely to be dressed in a T-shirt and jeans as in a suit and tie. What’s more, compared with other forms of entertainment, prices are very reasonable. Tickets for the BBC Symphony Orchestra at the Barbican in London, for instance, start at £12, or less if you take advantage of a young person’s scheme – certainly cheaper than a football match or the cinema in London, and not much to witness 90 professional musicians playing some of the world’s greatest music.

Enjoy in unexpected places
Most performances take place in concert halls, but classical music is very diverse – some concerts will feature a full symphony orchestra, others just a choir, a string quartet or even a solo pianist. Pieces for these smaller ensembles are called chamber music and are often presented in more intimate spaces, but over the past 10 years or so there has been a movement to present classical music outside of traditional venues altogether. The Multi-Story Orchestra, for instance, consists of young professional musicians playing a classical summer series at a multi-storey car park in London’s Peckham. Then there is Nonclassical, founded by classical composer and dance, grime, electro and hip-hop producer Gabriel Prokofiev, which puts on regular classical music gigs in pubs.

Silence is not always golden
When it comes to concert etiquette, most concert halls – like most theatres – expect a degree of quiet attention from the audience. However, some organisations, such as BBC National Orchestra of Wales offer no-rules concerts. In its Classical Playlist: Live, audience members are encouraged to walk around, have a drink, keep their phones on and even take photos (Brangwyn Hall, Swansea, 5 October 2019). English National Opera (the London-based company that performs all its repertoire in English) is offering a relaxed performance of Gilbert and Sullivan’s comedy The Mikado, to encourage autistic adults and children to attend, inviting them to make noise if they like, while dimming the lights and removing any loud noises (23 November 2019).

Beginners welcome
As for not knowing what’s going on, all concerts provide a programme to read, explaining the background to the music you are hearing, and these are often free. The BBC even has a Discover New Music series, which includes its day-long Total Immersion events. (On 7 December 2019 at the Barbican, London, German composer Detlev Glanert’s work will be explored through film, interview and concerts with the BBC Singers and BBC Symphony Orchestra and Chorus.) Meanwhile, there’s also a series entitled Classical for Starters – the BBC Concert Orchestra’s recent Orchestra Unwrapped saw Alice Farnham conducting pieces by Mozart and Stravinsky, alongside well-known film music by John Williams. A month later, Dalia Stasevska conducts the BBC Symphony Orchestra in Rachmaninov’s sprightly Symphonic Dances (26 October 2019, Barbican, London). You may have noted that the conductors just mentioned are both women – the days of exclusively male orchestras conducted by old men are long gone. Indeed, BBC Symphony Orchestra has just appointed young British conductor Jules Buckley as its new creative artist in association. Buckley says he is eager “to innovate and challenge the stereotypes of what orchestral music should be”. His first concert with the orchestra will be at the Barbican, London, on Friday 28 February 2020 and features soul singer Lianne La Havas. Previously, Buckley has joined in the BBC Proms concerts at the Royal Albert Hall with diverse programmes such as this year’s The Breaks, exploring the world of scratch DJs, hip-hop and breakdancing (6 September 2019).

Related: Five ways to get your family into classical music

A millennium of variety
Finally, the assumption that classical music all sounds the same is clearly erroneous, given that it stretches back nearly a thousand years. From choirs singing mediaeval vocal polyphony, Tudor viol consorts, to songs for piano and voice, and vast modern-day orchestras, the scale and variety of music is incomparable. So while the incredible works of Mozart, Beethoven and Brahms will always have a place on the concert platform, there are plenty of pieces by modern, living composers too. Anna Meredith’s music, for example, embraces both electronica and traditional instruments – she has even written a Concerto for Orchestra and Beatboxer. Then there’s David Lang, whose fresh take on Beethoven’s Fidelio, Prisoner of the State, is a stripped-down opera with the orchestra on stage (11 January, Barbican). Spanning everything from medieval polyphony to beatboxing, there is no one single thing that is classical music – and the same is true for its audiences. All you have to do is turn up, buy a ticket and enjoy.

Start your classical music journey with concerts from the BBC’s Classical for Starters series

webTitle: Man arrested outside office of Labour MP Jess Phillips

fields.headline: Man arrested outside office of Labour MP Jess Phillips
fields.standfirst: Man allegedly tried to smash windows after Phillips tabled urgent question in the Commons on inflammatory language
fields.trailText: Man allegedly tried to smash windows after Phillips tabled urgent question in the Commons on inflammatory language
fields.body:
A man has been arrested on suspicion of a public order offence following an incident outside the constituency office of the Labour MP Jess Phillips, in which the suspect is reported to have banged on the windows and shouted “fascist”.

Phillips, who represents Birmingham Yardley, said her staff had to be locked in the office while the man tried to smash the windows.

She told LBC Radio: “I’ve only just heard about it myself, but my staff had to be locked into my office while the man tried to smash the windows and kick the door, I believe.

“I don’t know what I can say because the man has been arrested. But he was shouting that I was a fascist, apparently.”

West Midlands police confirmed a 36-year-old man had been arrested outside the office on Yardley Road in Acocks Green, Birmingham.

The incident came after Phillips tabled an urgent question to the Commons on the subject of inflammatory language.

Phillips has frequently spoken about the abuse she has received at the hands of internet trolls, including threats of rape.

After the prime minister, Boris Johnson, denied accusations that his language was being appropriated by abusers, Phillips shared an image of a death threat she had received on paper that read: “It was rather prophetic that Boris Johnson should say: ‘I would rather be found dead in a ditch.’ That is what will happen to those who do not deliver Brexit.”

A statement by West Midlands police said: “Police were called to reports of a disturbance outside an address on Yardley Road in Acocks Green, Birmingham just before 2.25pm this afternoon [26 September].

“A 36-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of a public order offence and possession of cannabis. He’s been taken into police custody and will be questioned in due course.”
